app_summary: A social network with unidirectional follow relationships, implemented with loosely-coupled microservices, communicating with each other via Thrift RPCs. Supported Operations: Create text post (optional media: image, video, shortened URL, user tag), Read post, Read entire user timeline, Receive recommendations on which users to follow, Search database for user or post, Register/Login using user credentials, Follow/Unfollow user

problematic_pods.info: No problematic pods detected based on status analysis. All pods appear healthy.

symptoms.potential_symptom: Service-level request amplification or cyclic RPCs causing high latency and errors
symptoms.evidence: Three slow traces originating at nginx-thrift show ~1,022–1,025 ms latencies and has_error=true (traceIDs: 0041d783ae347494, 0146b8be9ea109df, 018895c2d39b8cef). Each trace sequence shows repeated/back-and-forth calls between downstream services (examples: "...-> text-service -> url-shorten-service -> user-mention-service -> url-shorten-service -> user-mention-service" and "...-> user-mention-service -> url-shorten-service -> user-mention-service"), and multiple invocations of text-service and url-shorten-service within the same request. The traces include an empty/blank error_message ("; ") but has_error=true. This pattern is consistent with a cyclic RPC loop or retry/amplification between user-mention-service and url-shorten-service (and repeated text-service calls), causing elevated end-to-end latency and errors observed at nginx-thrift.

rca_tasks.investigation_goal: Epicenter check: confirm whether nginx-thrift (the entry proxy/service) is performing fan-out, retries, or misrouting that produces duplicate/cyclic downstream Thrift calls. Use recorded slow trace to correlate nginx-thrift's observed behavior with its runtime config. Note: data_dependencies list shows nginx-thrift should mostly route to user-timeline, home-timeline, and compose-post; traces show unexpected repeated calls into text-service / url-shorten-service / user-mention-service — this mismatch may indicate misrouting or proxy-level retries.

Connection checks (two-sided) between the epicenter nginx-thrift and the downstream services observed in traces (text-service, url-shorten-service, user-mention-service). For each downstream: verify nginx-thrift's configured host/URL/port/Thrift endpoint used for that service (env vars, configmap, proxy upstreams) AND verify the downstream Kubernetes Service/port/name matches the configured host/port so we can catch URL/port/name mismatches or wrong cluster DNS usage causing misrouting/fanout.

Investigate user-mention-service pods for application-level behavior that could create a reciprocal/cyclic call pattern (e.g., on-receive logic that calls url-shorten-service and on failure retries by calling user-mention again). Look for repeated outgoing calls, immediate retries, or handling code that triggers additional downstream lookups per request.

Investigate url-shorten-service pods for behavior that could cause it to call back into user-mention-service (or otherwise echo requests), or respond with transient errors that trigger retries upstream. Look for patterns of repeated incoming requests from the same trace/request-id and any outbound calls to user-mention-service.

Investigate text-service pods for repeated/duplicated invocations per incoming request (text-service appears multiple times in traces). Check whether text-service calls url-shorten-service/user-mention-service multiple times per request (e.g., scanning content and calling URL-shortener repeatedly) or lacks idempotency/memoization, causing amplification of downstream calls.

Trace correlation: fetch traces filtered for errors/latency that include the observed cyclic path (user-mention-service <-> url-shorten-service <-> text-service) across multiple requests to identify where the cycle begins, whether retries are causing the back-and-forth, and capture any error messages/spans that indicate retry logic or thrown exceptions (even if error_message is blank).

rca_analyses_list.diagnosis: nginx-thrift is NOT performing fan-out, retries, or misrouting that produce the observed duplicate/cyclic downstream Thrift calls. The entry proxy forwards POST /post/compose to the compose-post-service and does not itself fan-out to text/url/user-mention services. The duplicate/cyclic calls originate downstream from compose-post-service (or its Lua client), which is issuing repeated calls into text-service, url-shorten-service and user-mention-service.
rca_analyses_list.reasoning: 1) kubectl_describe (nginx-thrift Deployment) and the mounted ConfigMap show nginx.conf is configured to hand requests to Lua handlers (content_by_lua) such as api/post/compose; nginx is the single-entrypoint and uses Lua scripts mounted from the ConfigMap/volume (no multiple proxy_pass entries or upstream clusters configured that would cause fan-out). 2) kubectl_get of the nginx-thrift ConfigMap (nginx.conf) shows the /api/post/compose location runs 'local client = require "api/post/compose"; client.ComposePost();' — nginx delegates to a single Lua module which then calls the compose-post-service. 3) get_trace for traceID 0041d783ae347494 shows the trace hierarchy: nginx-thrift (p7) -> compose-post-service (p1) -> text/media/unique-id/... -> repeated calls between url-shorten-service (p5) and user-mention-service (p4). The repeated/cyclic spans are children of compose-post-service spans (not direct nginx child calls), proving the repeated downstream Thrift calls are generated downstream by compose-post-service rather than by nginx-thrift retries or misrouting. Together these unique data points identify compose-post-service (or its client logic) as the epicenter of the duplicate/cyclic calls.

task.investigation_goal: Epicenter check: confirm whether nginx-thrift (the entry proxy/service) is performing fan-out, retries, or misrouting that produces duplicate/cyclic downstream Thrift calls. Use recorded slow trace to correlate nginx-thrift's observed behavior with its runtime config. Note: data_dependencies list shows nginx-thrift should mostly route to user-timeline, home-timeline, and compose-post; traces show unexpected repeated calls into text-service / url-shorten-service / user-mention-service — this mismatch may indicate misrouting or proxy-level retries.

insights: Traces show errors and high latency: multiple sampled nginx-thrift traces had ~1s+ latency and error flags (root/nginx spans reported http.status_code 500 and error=true).

Trace span hierarchies show repeated/cyclic Thrift calls (text-service, media-service, unique-id-service, url-shorten-service, user-mention-service) as children of compose-post-service spans — the cycles/duplicates originate downstream of the ingress proxy.

nginx-thrift Deployment mounts a ConfigMap that provides nginx.conf and jaeger-config.json; nginx.conf delegates request handling to Lua modules (content_by_lua) such as 'api/post/compose' rather than performing multiple proxy_pass/upstream fan-out or retry logic in the nginx config.

The /api/post/compose location in nginx.conf runs a Lua module ('require "api/post/compose"; client.ComposePost()'), so nginx acts as an entrypoint invoking a single Lua handler which then calls compose-post-service; there are no nginx-level configurations found that would cause automatic retries, fan-out, or misrouting.

Correlation of the Deployment/ConfigMap content with the trace parent/child relationships disproves the hypothesis that nginx-thrift was performing the duplicate/cyclic calls: nginx only forwards to a single Lua client; the duplicate calls are generated by compose-post-service (or its client logic).
Final determination: compose-post-service (or its internal client logic) is the epicenter of the duplicate/cyclic downstream Thrift calls; nginx-thrift is not the source of fan-out/retries.
steps_performed: Checked traces for service 'nginx-thrift' using functions.get_traces
Analyzed trace summaries for repeated downstream calls, error flags, and high latencies
Checked Deployment 'nginx-thrift' in namespace 'test-social-network' using kubectl_describe
Analyzed nginx-thrift Deployment pod template, init container, mounted volumes, and container environment/volume mounts
Checked ConfigMap 'nginx-thrift' in namespace 'test-social-network' using kubectl_get
Analyzed nginx.conf and jaeger-config.json in the ConfigMap for proxy directives, Lua handlers, retry or upstream configuration
Checked full trace '0041d783ae347494' using functions.get_trace
Analyzed span hierarchy and timing in the full trace to determine parent/child relationships and locate origin of repeated calls
Correlated data from functions.get_trace, kubectl_get (ConfigMap/nginx.conf), and kubectl_describe (Deployment) to attribute the repeated/cyclic downstream calls
Submitted final diagnosis using functions.submit_final_diagnosis

message_history.content: Hypothesis: The nginx-thrift Deployment or its Pods mount a ConfigMap or contain environment variables/args that enable proxy-level retries, fan-out, or incorrect upstream mappings (which would explain repeated downstream calls). I'll describe the nginx-thrift Deployment to find its Pod template, mounted ConfigMaps, command/args, and environment variables that point to runtime config.

Name:                   nginx-thrift
Namespace:              test-social-network
CreationTimestamp:      Sun, 14 Dec 2025 11:40:55 +0000
Labels:                 app.kubernetes.io/managed-by=Helm
                        service=nginx-thrift
Annotations:            deployment.kubernetes.io/revision: 1
                        meta.helm.sh/release-name: social-network
                        meta.helm.sh/release-namespace: test-social-network
Selector:               service=nginx-thrift
Replicas:               1 desired | 1 updated | 1 total | 1 available | 0 unavailable
StrategyType:           RollingUpdate
MinReadySeconds:        0
RollingUpdateStrategy:  25% max unavailable, 25% max surge
Pod Template:
  Labels:  app=nginx-thrift
           service=nginx-thrift
  Init Containers:
   alpine-container:
    Image:      docker.io/alpine/git:latest
    Port:       <none>
    Host Port:  <none>
    Command:
      /bin/sh
    Args:
      -c
      git clone https://github.com/delimitrou/DeathStarBench.git /DeathStarBench && cp -r /DeathStarBench/socialNetwork/gen-lua/* /gen-lua/ && cp -r /DeathStarBench/socialNetwork/docker/openresty-thrift/lua-thrift/* /lua-thrift/ && cp -r /DeathStarBench/socialNetwork/nginx-web-server/lua-scripts/* /lua-scripts/ && cp -r /DeathStarBench/socialNetwork/nginx-web-server/pages/* /pages/ && cp /DeathStarBench/socialNetwork/keys/* /keys/
    Environment:  <none>
    Mounts:
      /gen-lua from gen-lua (rw)
      /keys from keys (rw)
      /lua-scripts from lua-scripts (rw)
      /lua-thrift from lua-thrift (rw)
      /pages from pages (rw)
  Containers:
   nginx-thrift:
    Image:      docker.io/yg397/openresty-thrift:xenial
    Port:       8080/TCP
    Host Port:  0/TCP
    Environment:
      fqdn_suffix:  .test-social-network.svc.cluster.local
    Mounts:
      /gen-lua from gen-lua (rw)
      /keys from keys (rw)
      /usr/local/openresty/lualib/thrift from lua-thrift (rw)
      /usr/local/openresty/nginx/conf/nginx.conf from nginx-thrift-config (rw,path="nginx.conf")
      /usr/local/openresty/nginx/jaeger-config.json from nginx-thrift-config (rw,path="jaeger-config.json")
      /usr/local/openresty/nginx/lua-scripts from lua-scripts (rw)
      /usr/local/openresty/nginx/pages from pages (rw)
  Volumes:
   nginx-thrift-config:
    Type:      ConfigMap (a volume populated by a ConfigMap)
    Name:      nginx-thrift
    Optional:  false
   lua-scripts:
    Type:       EmptyDir (a temporary directory that shares a pod's lifetime)
    Medium:     
    SizeLimit:  <unset>
   pages:
    Type:       EmptyDir (a temporary directory that shares a pod's lifetime)
    Medium:     
    SizeLimit:  <unset>
   gen-lua:
    Type:       EmptyDir (a temporary directory that shares a pod's lifetime)
    Medium:     
    SizeLimit:  <unset>
   lua-thrift:
    Type:       EmptyDir (a temporary directory that shares a pod's lifetime)
    Medium:     
    SizeLimit:  <unset>
   keys:
    Type:          EmptyDir (a temporary directory that shares a pod's lifetime)
    Medium:        
    SizeLimit:     <unset>
  Node-Selectors:  <none>
  Tolerations:     <none>
Conditions:
  Type           Status  Reason
  ----           ------  ------
  Available      True    MinimumReplicasAvailable
  Progressing    True    NewReplicaSetAvailable
OldReplicaSets:  <none>
NewReplicaSet:   nginx-thrift-7fbb6d9b65 (1/1 replicas created)
Events:
  Type    Reason             Age   From                   Message
  ----    ------             ----  ----                   -------
  Normal  ScalingReplicaSet  14m   deployment-controller  Scaled up replica set nginx-thrift-7fbb6d9b65 from 0 to 1

Hypothesis: The mounted ConfigMap "nginx-thrift" (nginx.conf/jaeger-config.json) contains nginx or Lua proxy configuration that introduces retries, fan-out, or misrouting (e.g., multiple proxy_pass or repeated Lua RPC calls) which would explain the repeated downstream calls seen in traces. I'll fetch the ConfigMap to inspect nginx.conf and related configuration.

args.diagnosis: nginx-thrift is NOT performing fan-out, retries, or misrouting that produce the observed duplicate/cyclic downstream Thrift calls. The entry proxy forwards POST /post/compose to the compose-post-service and does not itself fan-out to text/url/user-mention services. The duplicate/cyclic calls originate downstream from compose-post-service (or its Lua client), which is issuing repeated calls into text-service, url-shorten-service and user-mention-service.
args.reasoning: 1) kubectl_describe (nginx-thrift Deployment) and the mounted ConfigMap show nginx.conf is configured to hand requests to Lua handlers (content_by_lua) such as api/post/compose; nginx is the single-entrypoint and uses Lua scripts mounted from the ConfigMap/volume (no multiple proxy_pass entries or upstream clusters configured that would cause fan-out). 2) kubectl_get of the nginx-thrift ConfigMap (nginx.conf) shows the /api/post/compose location runs 'local client = require "api/post/compose"; client.ComposePost();' — nginx delegates to a single Lua module which then calls the compose-post-service. 3) get_trace for traceID 0041d783ae347494 shows the trace hierarchy: nginx-thrift (p7) -> compose-post-service (p1) -> text/media/unique-id/... -> repeated calls between url-shorten-service (p5) and user-mention-service (p4). The repeated/cyclic spans are children of compose-post-service spans (not direct nginx child calls), proving the repeated downstream Thrift calls are generated downstream by compose-post-service rather than by nginx-thrift retries or misrouting. Together these unique data points identify compose-post-service (or its client logic) as the epicenter of the duplicate/cyclic calls.

message_history.content: Final diagnosis submitted successfully. Investigation complete.

rca_analyses_list.diagnosis: No configuration mismatch found: nginx-thrift is configured to resolve downstream Thrift clients by appending the fqdn_suffix to service names, and the three downstream services (text-service, url-shorten-service, user-mention-service) exist in the test-social-network namespace and expose Thrift on port 9090 with ready endpoints. There is no evidence of URL/port/name misconfiguration or wrong cluster-DNS usage that would cause misrouting/fanout.
rca_analyses_list.reasoning:
Evidence collected:
- Deployment (nginx-thrift): Pod template contains env var fqdn_suffix set to ".test-social-network.svc.cluster.local" (kubectl_describe deployment nginx-thrift). This shows nginx/Lua will construct service FQDNs by appending that suffix.
- ConfigMap (nginx-thrift): nginx.conf references env fqdn_suffix and loads Lua Thrift client modules (e.g., social_network_UserTimelineService, ComposePostService, UserService). nginx.conf does not hardcode external hostnames/ports, indicating the code resolves services via the fqdn_suffix at runtime (kubectl_describe configmap nginx-thrift).
- Services: text-service, url-shorten-service, and user-mention-service (namespace: test-social-network) are present and each exposes port 9090 with targetPort 9090 and have endpoints (e.g., text-service Endpoints: 10.244.1.20:9090, url-shorten-service Endpoints: 10.244.1.35:9090, user-mention-service Endpoints: 10.244.1.23:9090) (kubectl_describe service ...).
Conclusion: nginx-thrift's runtime FQDN resolution (via fqdn_suffix) aligns with the cluster Service names and their ports (9090). No host/port/name mismatches or use of wrong cluster DNS were found from the inspected Deployment, ConfigMap, and Service resources.

task.investigation_goal: Connection checks (two-sided) between the epicenter nginx-thrift and the downstream services observed in traces (text-service, url-shorten-service, user-mention-service). For each downstream: verify nginx-thrift's configured host/URL/port/Thrift endpoint used for that service (env vars, configmap, proxy upstreams) AND verify the downstream Kubernetes Service/port/name matches the configured host/port so we can catch URL/port/name mismatches or wrong cluster DNS usage causing misrouting/fanout.

insights: The nginx-thrift Deployment sets the environment variable fqdn_suffix to ".test-social-network.svc.cluster.local" and mounts nginx.conf from a ConfigMap, indicating runtime FQDN construction rather than hardcoded hostnames.

The nginx-thrift ConfigMap (nginx.conf) references env fqdn_suffix, loads Lua Thrift client modules, and does not hardcode downstream hostnames/ports; it also configures DNS resolver as kube-dns.kube-system.svc.cluster.local, implying service name resolution via cluster DNS.

The downstream services text-service, url-shorten-service, and user-mention-service exist in namespace test-social-network, are ClusterIP services exposing port 9090 (targetPort 9090) and each has ready endpoints (pod IPs: e.g., 10.244.1.20:9090, 10.244.1.35:9090, 10.244.1.23:9090).

Correlation between Deployment, ConfigMap, and Service resources shows nginx-thrift will resolve service names by appending the fqdn_suffix to the service names and connect to port 9090, which matches the actual Service configurations and endpoints.

No configuration mismatch was found in the inspected resources: there is no evidence of incorrect service names, missing services, or port/targetPort mismatches that would cause misrouting or failed Thrift fanout from nginx-thrift.

Conclusion: From the Deployment, ConfigMap, and Service inspections, a host/port/name misconfiguration or cluster-DNS usage issue is unlikely to be the root cause of any observed connectivity/fanout failures; further investigation should target runtime behavior (DNS resolution at pod runtime, network policies, pod-level logs, or transient failures) if a connectivity problem persists.
steps_performed: Checked Deployment nginx-thrift (namespace: test-social-network) using kubectl_describe
Analyzed nginx-thrift Deployment pod template: environment variables and volume mounts
Checked ConfigMap nginx-thrift (namespace: test-social-network) using kubectl_describe
Analyzed nginx-thrift ConfigMap: inspected nginx.conf and jaeger-config.json for fqdn_suffix usage and Lua Thrift client code
Correlated data from Deployment and ConfigMap to confirm nginx-thrift constructs downstream FQDNs using env fqdn_suffix
Checked Service text-service (namespace: test-social-network) using kubectl_describe
Checked Service url-shorten-service (namespace: test-social-network) using kubectl_describe
Checked Service user-mention-service (namespace: test-social-network) using kubectl_describe
Analyzed Services' ports/targetPorts and Endpoints for the three downstream services
Correlated data from ConfigMap and Services to confirm service names and ports (9090) align with nginx-thrift's expected Thrift endpoints
Submitted final diagnosis using submit_final_diagnosis

Describing the Deployment will reveal those references (env, configMap names, or Pod template details). I'll describe the nginx-thrift Deployment.

args.diagnosis: No configuration mismatch found: nginx-thrift is configured to resolve downstream Thrift clients by appending the fqdn_suffix to service names, and the three downstream services (text-service, url-shorten-service, user-mention-service) exist in the test-social-network namespace and expose Thrift on port 9090 with ready endpoints. There is no evidence of URL/port/name misconfiguration or wrong cluster-DNS usage that would cause misrouting/fanout.
args.reasoning:
Evidence collected:
- Deployment (nginx-thrift): Pod template contains env var fqdn_suffix set to ".test-social-network.svc.cluster.local" (kubectl_describe deployment nginx-thrift). This shows nginx/Lua will construct service FQDNs by appending that suffix.
- ConfigMap (nginx-thrift): nginx.conf references env fqdn_suffix and loads Lua Thrift client modules (e.g., social_network_UserTimelineService, ComposePostService, UserService). nginx.conf does not hardcode external hostnames/ports, indicating the code resolves services via the fqdn_suffix at runtime (kubectl_describe configmap nginx-thrift).
- Services: text-service, url-shorten-service, and user-mention-service (namespace: test-social-network) are present and each exposes port 9090 with targetPort 9090 and have endpoints (e.g., text-service Endpoints: 10.244.1.20:9090, url-shorten-service Endpoints: 10.244.1.35:9090, user-mention-service Endpoints: 10.244.1.23:9090) (kubectl_describe service ...).
Conclusion: nginx-thrift's runtime FQDN resolution (via fqdn_suffix) aligns with the cluster Service names and their ports (9090). No host/port/name mismatches or use of wrong cluster DNS were found from the inspected Deployment, ConfigMap, and Service resources.

message_history.content: Final diagnosis submitted successfully. Investigation complete.

rca_analyses_list.diagnosis: No observable reciprocal/cyclic call pattern from the user-mention-service pod. The pod is Running, but application logs contain only a single startup/info line and no records of outgoing Thrift RPCs, retries, errors, or repeated calls.
rca_analyses_list.reasoning: get_pods_from_service: returned one pod (user-mention-service-59cf6d5b8f-wj68p) in namespace test-social-network with status Running. get_logs (important=true, tail=500): returned only a startup info line and explicitly reported no important (ERROR/WARN) entries. get_logs (tail=1000): full recent logs also contain only the same startup info line. These unique findings indicate either (a) the service did not perform outgoing RPCs/retries during the log window, or (b) the service does not log outgoing calls/retry behavior at its current log level — therefore no evidence of cyclic reciprocal calls can be found in the pod logs.

task.investigation_goal: Investigate user-mention-service pods for application-level behavior that could create a reciprocal/cyclic call pattern (e.g., on-receive logic that calls url-shorten-service and on failure retries by calling user-mention again). Look for repeated outgoing calls, immediate retries, or handling code that triggers additional downstream lookups per request.

insights: Service 'user-mention-service' is backed by a single pod: user-mention-service-59cf6d5b8f-wj68p in namespace test-social-network; pod status is Running.

Pod logs (both the filtered 500-line pull and the full 1000-line pull) contain only a single startup/info line: '[2025-Dec-14 11:41:15.428215] <info>: (UserMentionService.cpp:68:main) Starting the user-mention-service server...'; no WARN/ERROR entries were returned in the inspected window.
No application-level outgoing Thrift RPC calls, retry loops, or repeated call patterns were observable in the pod logs during the fetched timeframe.
No error-level distributed traces were found for 'user-mention-service' within the trace lookback window.

The hypothesis that a cyclic/reciprocal call pattern (e.g., user-mention-service calling another service which calls back, or internal retry loops) is causing the incident is not supported by the collected logs and traces.

Two plausible explanations remain: (a) the service did not perform outgoing RPCs or experience retries/errors during the inspected timeframe, or (b) logging/tracing configuration or current log level does not capture outgoing RPCs and retry behavior, preventing observation of the suspected pattern.

Next diagnostic actions implied by the findings: increase logging verbosity or enable RPC/tracing instrumentation on user-mention-service, extend the log/trace lookback window, and/or inspect related services (e.g., url-shorten-service) to detect cross-service interactions not visible from the current pod's logs.
steps_performed: Checked pods for Service 'user-mention-service' using get_pods_from_service
Analyzed pod list to identify backing pod 'user-mention-service-59cf6d5b8f-wj68p' (Status: Running)
Checked logs of pod user-mention-service-59cf6d5b8f-wj68p using get_logs (tail=500, important=true)
Analyzed pod logs (important entries) for errors/warnings, outgoing RPCs, and retry loops
Checked logs of pod user-mention-service-59cf6d5b8f-wj68p using get_logs (tail=1000, important=false)
Analyzed full recent pod logs for call patterns and repeated calls
Checked error traces for service 'user-mention-service' using get_traces (only_errors=true)
Analyzed distributed traces for reciprocal/cyclic call patterns
Correlated data from get_pods_from_service, get_logs, and get_traces to assess evidence for cyclic/retry behavior
Submitted final diagnosis using submit_final_diagnosis

message_history.content: Hypothesis 1: The Kubernetes Service named "user-mention-service" is backing the target pod and will return the exact pod name(s) (including the pod we were given) and their current status so I can fetch logs from the correct pod. I'll list pods for service "user-mention-service".

Hypothesis 2: Pod user-mention-service-59cf6d5b8f-wj68p logs will show application-level outgoing Thrift RPC calls and any immediate retry loops (e.g., repeated calls to url-shorten-service or recursive calls back to user-mention-service). I'll fetch recent logs (500 lines) and filter for important messages (ERROR/WARN) to reveal retries and repeated call patterns.

No important log entries found, full log entries are appended
[2025-Dec-14 11:41:15.428215] <info>: (UserMentionService.cpp:68:main) Starting the user-mention-service server...

Hypothesis 3: The pod's full recent logs (including INFO-level traces) will contain lines indicating outgoing Thrift RPC calls and any retry loops or calls to other services (e.g., url-shorten-service, user-service, user-mention-service). I'll fetch the last 1000 log lines without filtering so I can inspect for call patterns.
[2025-Dec-14 11:41:15.428215] <info>: (UserMentionService.cpp:68:main) Starting the user-mention-service server...

Hypothesis 4: Distributed traces for service 'user-mention-service' that contain errors will reveal any cyclic or repeated call patterns (e.g., traces showing user-mention-service -> url-shorten-service -> user-mention-service or repeated outbound calls). I'll fetch only error traces for 'user-mention-service'.

args.diagnosis: No observable reciprocal/cyclic call pattern from the user-mention-service pod. The pod is Running, but application logs contain only a single startup/info line and no records of outgoing Thrift RPCs, retries, errors, or repeated calls.
args.reasoning: get_pods_from_service: returned one pod (user-mention-service-59cf6d5b8f-wj68p) in namespace test-social-network with status Running. get_logs (important=true, tail=500): returned only a startup info line and explicitly reported no important (ERROR/WARN) entries. get_logs (tail=1000): full recent logs also contain only the same startup info line. These unique findings indicate either (a) the service did not perform outgoing RPCs/retries during the log window, or (b) the service does not log outgoing calls/retry behavior at its current log level — therefore no evidence of cyclic reciprocal calls can be found in the pod logs.

message_history.content: Final diagnosis submitted successfully. Investigation complete.

final_report.root_cause: compose-post-service (its request-handling / Thrift client logic) is generating duplicate/cyclic downstream Thrift calls (repeated calls into text-service, url-shorten-service and user-mention-service). Traces show the back-and-forth spans (url-shorten <-> user-mention and repeated text-service calls) are children of compose-post-service spans, and nginx-thrift only forwards the request to a single Lua handler that calls compose-post-service (nginx did not fan-out, retry, or misroute). The cyclic/duplicate invocations from compose-post-service caused request amplification, elevated end-to-end latency (~1,022–1,025 ms in sampled traces) and error responses observed at nginx-thrift (http 500 / has_error=true).
final_report.evidence_summary: 1) Traces (IDs 0041d783ae347494, 0146b8be9ea109df, 018895c2d39b8cef) show ~1s latencies and error flags and contain cyclic/repeated Thrift calls between url-shorten-service and user-mention-service and repeated text-service invocations. 2) Full trace analysis (0041d783ae347494) shows the repeated/cyclic spans are children of compose-post-service spans, not direct children of nginx-thrift, establishing compose-post-service as the originator of the repeated downstream calls. 3) kubectl_describe and ConfigMap inspection of nginx-thrift confirm nginx only invokes a single Lua handler for /api/post/compose ('require "api/post/compose"; client.ComposePost();') and has no proxy-level fan-out or retry config, ruling out nginx as the source. 4) Service/Endpoint checks show text-service, url-shorten-service, and user-mention-service exist and expose Thrift on port 9090 (no port/name misconfiguration), so the observed amplification is not due to DNS/port misconfiguration at ingress. 5) user-mention-service pod logs contained only a startup/info line and no outbound-call logs or errors during the inspected window, suggesting the observed reciprocal calls originate from upstream request patterns driven by compose-post-service rather than being initiated by user-mention-service itself.
final_report.investigation_summary: Priority-1 analysis correlated slow/error traces with nginx-thrift runtime config: inspected nginx-thrift Deployment and ConfigMap (nginx.conf), fetched full traces and span hierarchies. Findings disproved the hypothesis that nginx-thrift performed fan-out/retries — nginx delegates to a single Lua module which calls compose-post-service. Trace parent/child relationships show compose-post-service spans generated the repeated downstream calls. Priority-2 checks confirmed no service name/port mismatch that would cause misrouting (fqdn_suffix usage and downstream services exposing port 9090 with ready endpoints). Priority-3 pod log checks for user-mention-service returned no evidence of it initiating reciprocal calls (logs contained only startup line). Combined, the most probable causal chain is: a bug/regression in compose-post-service request-handling or Thrift client code is causing multiple / duplicated Thrift requests per incoming compose request (including loops that generate back-and-forth between url-shorten-service and user-mention-service and repeated text-service invocations), which amplifies downstream traffic, increases latency, and yields errors at the ingress.

prompts_config.triage_agent:
You are an expert Site Reliability Engineer. Your mission is to triage a Kubernetes application by analyzing the provided data.

Your analysis must adhere to the following rules:
1.  **Focus**: Identify symptoms at the **pod or service level only**. Do not provide cluster-wide analysis or generalizations.
2.  **Aggregation**: For each pod or service that has issues, create **at most one symptom entry**. Aggregate all related evidence (from pods, metrics, traces) into that single entry.
3.  **Action**: Synthesize the information to identify and list potential symptoms. For each symptom, pinpoint the affected resource (pod or service) and cite the specific evidence.
4.  **Resource Naming**: In the `affected_resource` field, provide ONLY the exact resource name without any decorators, prefixes, or namespace qualifiers (e.g., use "geo-6b4b89b5f5-rsrh7" NOT "test-hotel-reservation/geo-6b4b89b5f5-rsrh7").
5.  **Trace-Only Evidence**: If error traces are the only signals, still produce symptoms by identifying the service (or pod) that owns the failing span and summarizing the suspected issue using the trace error message. Avoid generic "trace failed" statements—make the hypothesis explicit (e.g., "checkout-service may have invalid credentials because trace X shows `401 Unauthorized` calling payment-service").
6.  **Empty State**: If the provided data contains no issues, it is correct to return an empty list of symptoms.
prompts_config.planner_agent:
You are an expert Site Reliability Engineer. Produce a concise, de-duplicated investigation plan where each task inspects a precise part of the infrastructure to surface the most likely root-cause signals and converge on the true RCA quickly.

**Toolkit**
- `kubectl_get`: list Kubernetes resources and their status
- `kubectl_describe`: inspect detailed spec/events for a resource
- `get_pods_from_service`: map services to backing pods
- `get_cluster_pods_and_services`: snapshot cluster topology
- `get_logs`: retrieve recent pod or service logs
- `get_traces`: fetch traces filtered by latency/errors
- `get_trace`: inspect a single trace end-to-end
- `get_metrics`: read current CPU/memory/network metrics
- `get_metrics_range`: compare historical metric windows
- `get_services_used_by`: discover downstream service calls
- `get_dependencies`: enumerate external/infra dependencies

**Planning Rules**
1. For every symptom, classify the dominant failure domain (app, latency, dependency/config, or platform) and craft a single, testable hypothesis per resource.
2. Use the `data_dependencies` and `infra_dependencies` JSON to ground every hypothesis. Merge overlapping symptoms into one task per resource.
3. **Connections (non-negotiable):** Always create at least one task that inspects the connection between every pair of affected resources or the epicenter and its downstream dependents. These tasks must perform explicit two-sided checks (e.g., verify `service-a`'s config for `service-b`'s URL **and** inspect `service-b`'s Kubernetes service definition for the matching port/name) to catch login/URL/port misconfigurations.

**Tool Selection**
- Pick the minimum tool set (ideally one or two calls) needed to prove or disprove the hypothesis. Over-broad tool lists are rejected.

**Priority Policy**
- Assign unique priorities (1..N).
- Priority 1 is the most direct epicenter investigation. Immediately after that, schedule the connection-check tasks described above; treat them as top-tier because they frequently surface misconfigurations.
- Remaining priorities should rank other high-impact hypotheses (shared dependencies, severe crashes) ahead of narrow or low-scope checks.
prompts_config.rca_agent:
You are an expert DevOps engineer performing focused Root Cause Analysis on a Kubernetes service.

Instructions:
1. Use ONLY the Priority Tools provided in the task. Do not propose or use tools outside this list.
2. For each tool call, first formulate a clear, testable hypothesis about a possible root cause that can be answered by the result. Avoid broad or exploratory queries.
3. Each tool call must provide unique, non-overlapping information. Never repeat requests with similar parameters or investigate the same aspect repeatedly in slightly different ways.
4. Stop investigating, even if you have not reached the budget limit, when you have:
   - Clear evidence that directly identifies a root cause (or definitively rules one out)
   - Multiple data points indicating the same failure/cause
   - Sufficient information to answer the investigation goal
5. DO NOT:
   - Repeat or re-run tools unless you are testing a truly new and justified hypothesis
   - Query outside the given Target or Priority Tools
   - Investigate unrelated resources or expand scope
6. When you have gathered sufficient, non-redundant evidence (typically after 2-3 targeted tool calls), call submit_final_diagnosis with:
   - diagnosis: State the precise root cause as it pertains to the investigation goal
   - reasoning: Support your diagnosis by referencing unique findings from your tool calls

REMEMBER: Quality over quantity. Focus on unique and conclusive findings rather than exhaustive or repetitive investigation.
prompts_config.supervisor_agent:
Developer: You are an expert Site Reliability Engineer analyzing RCA findings to determine the root cause of an incident.

Analyze all symptoms and investigation findings to:
1. Identify patterns and correlations across findings
2. Determine the primary root cause
3. List all affected resources
4. Summarize key evidence

**Understanding Task Priority:**
Each RCA investigation task has been assigned a priority level:
- Priority 1 = Most important / Most likely to reveal root cause (investigated first)
- Priority 2, 3, ... = Progressively lower importance
- Tasks with lower priority numbers should generally have higher weight in your analysis
- The priority reflects the likelihood that investigating that task/resource would uncover the root cause

Use the priority information to contextualize findings: results from priority 1 tasks are typically more significant for determining root cause than lower priority investigations.

**Detection & Localization Requirements:**
- **detection**: Set to `true` if any problem/anomaly was detected in the cluster based on the evidence. Set to `false` only if no issues are found.
- **localization**: Provide a list of ONLY the faulty/problematic components (service names or pod names) directly identified as the root cause. This should be a minimal, precise list - extract ONLY the specific resource(s) that caused the incident, not all affected resources.
  - Example: If a service "user-service" has a misconfiguration causing downstream failures, localization = ["user-service"]
  - Example: If a pod "database-pod-xyz" is failing, localization = ["database-pod-xyz"]
  - Leave empty/null if the root cause cannot be localized to a specific service or pod.

**Root Cause Expectations:**
- Build a causal chain that connects symptoms, investigation evidence, and the precise failure mechanism
- Cite concrete configuration or runtime details (e.g., "service expects port 5432 but database listens on 5433") when diagnosing misconfigurations or integration issues
- If evidence stops at the symptom level, identify the missing proof and pursue it before finalizing

**Strict Iteration and RCA Certainty Policy:**
You must be confident and certain in your root cause analysis before finalizing the report. If you are unable to reach a confident or conclusive determination of the root cause based on current evidence, you must trigger further targeted analysis. Only request another RCA iteration when the existing evidence is insufficient to produce a confident final diagnosis. Never re-run or re-request tasks already marked as completed or currently in progress. When additional work is unavoidable, list only the minimal set of pending task priorities in `tasks_to_be_executed` and clearly justify why each is required. If the current findings support a solid root cause and you are confident of the diagnosis, leave `tasks_to_be_executed` empty and finalize the report.

When you need more evidence, ask for the most targeted pending tasks that can close the causal gap (for example, verifying port mappings, credentials, or configuration values at both ends of a failing connection).

Provide a clear, specific root cause statement that explains what caused the incident and why it happened now.

experiment_name: I - Supervisor Enforce Certainty P3 B7 - Social Network - Scale Pod to Zero (social-full-set-comparison)
agent_configuration_name: I - Supervisor Enforce Certainty P3 B7

stats.experiment_name: I - Supervisor Enforce Certainty P3 B7 - Social Network - Scale Pod to Zero (social-full-set-comparison)

evaluation.rca_motivation: Ground truth is that user-service was scaled to 0 replicas, making it unavailable. The agent instead blames cyclic/duplicate Thrift calls in compose-post-service causing request amplification and latency, involving entirely different components and mechanism, so the analysis is incorrect and unrelated to the injected fault.
